Bad: On most nights there are random people that flood the place with good cheer and by good cheer I mean drugs, sex, drinking and urination. Fist fights and people rummaging through the recycle bins at 4 AM. will put damper on your sleep, but you get used to it. It kinda becomes like one of those wave radios that lulls you to sleep with the sounds of the ocean. With this sound track instead of occasionally hearing a wave crash you hear, "DO YOU WANT TO GO TO JAIL OR DO YOU WANT TO GO HOME?"
author: Corey V.

description: Pretty cool way to kill some time and especially if you're into graffiti art. There's also another alley called Lilac Alley in between 24 and 25th st that also has a lot of graffiti art. The Mission District where these alleys are located is a pretty cool place to check out in general. A lot of good bars and cool shops.
author: Josh B.

description: If you enjoy looking at cool graffiti, this is the place to go. There are a bunch of cool murals in an interesting neighborhood. The Mission area reminds me of Los Angeles since it's a bit more urban, diverse and ghetto. Some of the murals have been graffitied on (ironic), which is sad. I would think that there would be an unspoken rule not to ruin other people's graffiti.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Mission District - Mural Stop #5

The last stop on my Mission District exploration date with my boyfriend - Clarion Alley.  Walking through was like a free photo op in the Mission District!  Every angle you snap is amazing and full of color (and if you don't have a DSLR, this alley will make you want one REAAALLL bad.)

Now, some of the artwork isn't the best, but some art is full of detail, to the point where your face is soooo close to the wall, and you forget that it's a very very VERY dirty surface.  Womp.

In any case, many murals have a comical 'twist' and most will definitely make you smile.  There are so many talented artists in the area, and I'm just glad that they are able to show the public their work.  Easy access from public transportation (16th St. BART).  A hidden gem in SF, for sure.

And for free?  Yes, please.

Photographers that want to bust out their cameras for a good time?  Hit up Clarion Alley.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I used to live around the corner from this spot. It's true, the artwork is lovely. It's a great place to bring an out-of-town visitor to display how serious San Francisco is about its murals.

Just don't be caught here after dark. Seriously. I know it's a great short cut, but you might run into folks doing things you'd rather not see them doing in the middle of the street.
author: Beth K.

description: I'd totally forgotten about this area. Back in the day when I used to teach photography, film and video we took some of my students here to see what an artist in residence project/commune looked like. It seems like most people only see the murals and what not and dont realize what goes on behind the scenes. Definitely good for seeing the local art flavor of SF but if you want an in depth perspective, speak to some of the artists that live there!
author: Kim N.

description:
Great murals right off of Mission Street... 

The Clarion murals are in a short alley- marked by road sign on Mission- full of art. The murals in the Alley are probably the edgiest of all those I viewed in The Mission- very eye catching and imaginative. If you are visiting The Mission I would recommend them. 

FYI's~
* Only takes a few minutes to check out
* Larger pictures and objects then a lot of the other murals
* VERY close to 16th Street BART station
author: Natalie W.

description: A great display of art in the already very mural-filled Mission District.  This alley has some of the best.  Most does have a political point, be it local or national.  It is a great expression of the viewpoints of many San Franciscans, whether or not you agree with them.  Definitely worth the visit if you're in the City.
author: Raman S.

description: I'd have to say really cool art. My wife and I both went there just looking to explore different things in Frisco. Took some really cool pics, if your phone has a panoramic feature on it I would suggest using it when taking some pics looks really cool after you develop them. I would suggest anyone to go check this alley out can't wait to check out some more alleys in Frisco.
author: Da Bears S.

description: Walk, it's good for your health. Enjoy this beautiful city (Clarion Alley)  for it's unique culture, its respect for art, and love that is expressed via spray can..look straight ahead in awe!
author: sonia m.

description:
It stinks of piss and it's got great art. 

If you want a sterile environment void of anima and ammonia, go to MOMA.
author: Mr and Mrs G.

description:
Clarion Alley breathes murals and tags evolving over time. 

The simple Alleyway is transformed into telling stories. The political message some mural carries a distinctive SF flavor.
author: Jack C.

description:
It's an alley. The walls are covered with urban art. That's about it.

But anything that makes me think, anything that makes me look in wonder, anything that makes me curious about its undoubtedly colorful history, deserves 5 stars from me.
author: Diana L.

description: Clarion Alley has always been my go-to touch down when showing off my city to friends. This techicolor graffiti'd alley way is free, it's fresh... what more can you ask for? The dopeness.
author: Amber K.

description: Im from LA and glad I came here. LA has street art but not like this.
author: Crystal R.

description:
So glad I took my friends here.

A little startling when I knelt down to snap a shot, but paused due to the smell of urine that drew my attention to a used tampon... so certainly not for everybody, but man, the art was great, and from the look of things it's constantly changing!
author: James Y.

description:
I live behind this alley (my deck borders it).  

Clarion Alley is another one of SF's hidden gems.  It is covered in public art by local artists.  Murals cover every subject imaginable but have a dominant theme of social justice.  Just type in "Clarion Alley" on Flickr for a sample of some of the badass murals covering this street.

Precita Eyes (www.precitaeyes.org) also does mural tours.

[Minus one star only because the alley gets occasionally overrun by crack addicts who use it for a bathroom!]
author: Sid D.

description:
My best buddy from college was in town. 

He's a stay-at-home dad with two kids, lives in the suburbs of Seattle. Doesn't get out much, so I set up some regression therapy comprising drinking, playing Xbox 360, eating, and more drinking. On the fringes of this brutal regimen, I tried to ensure that he got some culture.

Clarion Alley was the last stop on an afternoon walk we'd taken from my apartment in Twin Peaks which included Dolores Park, lunch at Tartine, X21, Borderlands Bookstore ( sigh - no Ripley), and the Pirate Store. It was a beautiful day, and the alleyway was crowded with people checking out some new work on the walls. As we sauntered East toward Mission, I noticed some furtive movement on the right side of the alley about 25 yards in front of us. There was a guy pressed up against the fence, slightly stooped, looking for all the world like he was either stuck to, or merging with, the boards.

Turns out both were true. There was a little hole in the fence that he was trying to cram 'himself' into.

Now I have seen a lot of things in my 43 years on this planet. But I have never seen anyone work so desparately to achieve carnal bliss with a FENCE in broad daylight, and with an audience. 

I mean -- there is just no protocol that I know of that provides any helpful guidance on dealing with a situation like this. It's a bit of a conversation killer.

So we walked along in silence, both appalled and maybe a little amused, and tried to give this guy his privacy. However our friend -- let's just call him Woody Woodpecker -- wasn't having ANY of that . I guess he hadn't quite worked that knot out of the wood (if you know what I'm saying), because he stopped in mid-saw and began to berate us for, all jokes aside, "interrupting my nut". He yanked his pants up and strode purposefully up Balmy Street in the direction of the Mission police station.

Ah, San Francisco, city of art and culture. And carpentry!

We were glad to get back to the relative calm and sanity of the Castro.
author: Karsten P.

description: How many times do I walk down Mission/Valencia past Clarion Alley and not explore the amazing murals that have graced th walls and houses since 1992? Too many. CAMP (Clarion Alley Art Project) had a brilliant idea when they began this project. The list of artists who have participated would read like a memorial, there are so many. Rigo92, Sebastiana Pastor, Aracely Soriano, Jessica Miller..the list goes on. There's always at least two photographers in the alley taking photos of the work. People come from all around the world to see them but you have to be on foot. No S.F. tour bus is going to drive down Clarion Alley! Just another hidden gem of this city!
author: michael s.

description: Oooh Clarion Alley, you always shock me with unexpected color as I wonder down a dark, gray Valencia Street. I remember enjoying a stroll by your spot after leaving Amnesia. I decided to push the cute guy accompanying me onto your street, the perfect location for a kiss! But not for too long as it's probably not the safest place after hours.
author: Cyndie H.

description:
STINKY, but worth the occasional dry heave. 

Beautiful colours and punchy.

Even the tourists flock here!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Super awesome.  Minus 1 star for the urine stink.  

All the stars go towards the art and my friend Lauren's photography project in this alley!
author: Annster L.

description:
Wow, this a great collection of urban art!  

here are my pics:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/7342784@N04/sets/72157604420728361/detail/
author: Lauren C.

description: If you like street art and graffiti, bring your camera and plenty of memory card space. Watch your step. Deal with the odor. Leave happy with 30-50 photos of great pieces. Upload the good pics for others to enjoy.
author: Hunter B.

description:
Yes, it smells like pee but it's worth it! 

Every one who walks through this alley stops in their tracks to admire the art. It's sooo kool!! Best alley I've seen in SF! It's not even scary walking through it if you do it in the daytime. :) 

Also, I wish some people would stop doing graffiti tags over the beautiful artwork already on the walls! It's beginning to ruin them!
author: Bets Y.

description:
How could you NOT rate this five stars?

I mean, yeah....it starts to smell like piss once you get closer to Mission Street...but, dude....even my MOM from MISSOURI liked it!

Politically-charged, completely talented, absolutely unique, must-see-it-here-to-see-it-at-all.

And they throw one HELL of a block party.
author: Danyell K.

description:
I read about this in a local's guide and had to check it out. I haven't seen anything like this in any other city. 
A lot of times you can watch the artists work.
Occasionally there will be music show along the backgroup of the art, which is cool.

Neat spot worth checking out if you are in the neighborhood.
But I agree- places like this is what makes San Francisco such a cool city to live in.
author: Holly O.

description: Mission mural spot that makes for an interesting 10 min walk. I didn't find it as amazing as others but it is a nice diversion from shopping and eating
author: Andrew S.

description:
Five friggin' stars!
Clarion Alley is the best public bathroom in the Mission!
author: James C.

description: 50 or so vibrant graffiti murals line both sides of this alley in the Mission. This off the beaten path art project is great for cheap locals, urban photographers, and seasoned tourists. Some murals are artistic and beautiful, some have political messages, and others are wangster crap. I saw one that was dark, demonic, and nightmare inducing. I make sure to bring out of towners by here when we're killing time in the Mission.
author: R J.

description:
I love walking down this alley after a few hours of thrifting in Mission. It's perfect! However, I wish someone would clean up the Mission St end, it's so yucky. I always hold my breath and walk super fast when I get to the end.

One of these days I dream to venture down the alley with my BFF from LBC stoned and chill and see how much more cooler this place actually is. *Chham get your ass up here*

Anyways, it's a definite must see for tourist and perfect place to reconnectand appreciate SF.
author: Eclectic C.

description: I love street art, so I love this place. Totally worth stopping by to check out.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Posted up on a palm tree. Smoking a cigarette. Hop on my cruiser and start rolling from 17th St. down Mission, southwise.

Take a right at Clarion Alley. Enjoy the treat that hits your eyes. It is the representation of Mission in Graffiti form. Trust me, once you come here, you want to LIVE in the Mission. It worked for me. I live across the street now.
author: Haz O.

description: This is my favorite alley. The artwork is as diverse as it is incredible. If you're spending the day in the Mission, it is well worth checking out.
author: Tina H.

description: If you ever venture into the Mission district... I am telling you, you gotta check out the murals in clarion Valley.  My favorite mural would have to be the hearts of gold mural.  Definitely reminded me of what kind of woman I want to become.  Strength from a vulnerable perspective.  Also, these murals speak of the community in the mission district.  THEY really SPEAK.  and taking a stand towards social injustice through these beautiful murals, from the oppression of women to the oppression of cultures/ethnicities, is truly inspiring.  You gotta see... sit... and ponder.
author: Rainbow B.

description: True its stinky, but its well worth the smell! Great place to take friends from out of town for some great photos. Day time is the best time to go, and the best part is that its free! Don't miss this SF gem!
author: Gordon S.

description: This is one of my favorite mural alleyways in the mission. One of my dear friends did a mural in this alley and I even shot his brother's CD cover in front of the mural. I use it alot as an interesting backdrop for portraits. The only thing is that I would not wear open toe shoes and don't be surprised if you see some shady activity here.
author: Jennifer S.

description: We live above this alley and it's horrible, especially at night when the bars close and every one decides to pee there or hang out there and loudly discuss their nights conquest, one day when you are older and more mature and have respect for other human beings you will understand how annoying this is! The murrals that we have to look out our kitchen window at are terrible! I would love to see the city find another venue for this and close the alley at night so we can all sleep!
author: taylor l.

description: I love clarion alley.  I can't really say anything that hasn't been said in other reviews, so fuck it.  That's all you get.
author: Matt N.

description:
Balmy street and Clarion alley are by far the best place for street art in San Francisco and maybe even US. Balmy st is the older site and you can find guided tours from Precita Eyes.

Clarion is newer and the art has more anger in it. Don't be put off by the stink. And don't be scared. It is safe - at the end of the road is the local police station.

For a link to some high quality photos of the murals and more local flavor of these two streets: 

http://locomotoring.net/2008/07/24/mural-hunting-in-mission-district/


You will be happy to note that SFO is one of the best cities for mural art. Even Diego Rivera (http://diegorivera.com/index.php) painted murals here. 

Sometimes my out of town guests do get put off by the down to earth Mission district but for locals this is the place to go. So if you are an adventurous visitor, want to do what the local do, please visit Mission after the more obvious piers, north beach, china town and the union square. And if you are at Mission, you can't but not see the murals.

For a more complete trip of the Mission area, read on :

http://locomotoring.net/2008/12/29/three-hours-at-mission-district-of-san-francisco/
author: Mishti D.

description:
cool local art, all different styles, always changing, and totally free!
good for a taste of real SF culture, and a smell of real human urine. 
definitely only go during the day and enter from the valencia street end. turn around and walk back when the smell of piss gets too thick for normal breathing... and viola!
author: zachary p.

description: a truly san franciscan gem.  an alley full of interesting huge murals, covering walls, houses, fences.  stopped by the block party last night for some live music and crowds.  would like to learn more about the history here...if in sf, definitely stop by.
author: micaela r.

description: Who can justify paying $12 for a museum entrance fee when you can see the best art in SF for freezy?! I recently inherited the bfs castaway DSLR when he upgraded so I needed a quick lesson and some tips. What a great place for a self-guided photography walking tour! And yes it is worth it to hold your breath for a couple seconds when you crouch down right next to the dooodoo to capture the perfect shot. Granted Balmy Alley is less smelly....but Clarion is 2 blocks from Birite Creamery....the best way to purge your nose from all offending odors.
author: Emily W.
